thread.title: Las Vegas not Frank's kind of town anymore?
thread.title_full: Las Vegas not Frank's kind of town anymore? | Las Vegas Review-Journal

author: Norm Clarke
title: Las Vegas not Frank's kind of town anymore?
text:
Frank Sinatra impressionist Bob Anderson is taking his show on the road, saying "This is no longer a Sinatra, Darin , Bennett , Mathis or Tom Jones town. It is a Britney Spears town."
He posted the comments on his Facebook page earlier this week before removing them Wednesday. A news release was in the works, he said Thursday.
His last performance of "Frank: The Man. The Music." at the Palazzo will be Nov. 28. He opened in January and will be leaving about two weeks before what would have been Sinatra's 100th birthday, Dec. 12.
Reached by telephone Thursday, Anderson suggested he was blindsided by the move.
"It's a drag they (plan to close it) two weeks before Frank's birthday," he said.
But in his Facebook post he said the decision to leave was his.
"The hotel needs to do some work on the room for the next show that is coming in," he said.
Anderson said the show "has to go to where Frank Sinatra fans are living. They do not come to Las Vegas anymore."
He has had offers to take the show to Broadway, he said in the post.
"Someone asked me why don't I take the show down to a sextet and get a smaller room and keep the show in Las Vegas. Been there, done that!" he said.
Fashion furor
They might be the Bickering Bickersons of show business, but Wynonna Judd has a message: Don't mess with her momma.
The daughter didn't take kindly to celebrity writer Robin Leach 's harsh fashion critique of her mother's outfit.
Near the end of the Q&A at Tuesday's news conference in The Venetian theater, Naomi Judd playfully asked Leach what he thought of her white satin, feather-collared gown.
"I'll be really honest. I think it's hideous," Leach said.
After the media left, the Judds sat down with "Entertainment Tonight." Wynonna Judd grew upset that (Leach) went too far in "trashing her mother's style," according to an ET report.
"You know what?" Wynonna Judd told ET's Nischelle Turner . "She's my mom. If she wants to show up in spandex and a tube top, go girl!"
Turner, in her report, said the daughter was visibly upset about Leach's insult after the ET interview.
"He hurt your feelings. And I'm not going to let that happen," Wynonna Judd said. "If anyone's going to hurt your feelings, it's me."
Wynonna Judd came rushing into her mother's dressing room "like a raging bull," Naomi Judd said. Leach was coming to apologize, the daughter told her mother.
After attending the opening night show Wednesday, Leach tweeted what appeared to be a staged pose of Naomi leaning in to kiss him.
"Ignore any false stories in print or on tv," Leach tweeted. "Naomi & I are best pals & kiss to prove it after girls night out premier."
Wynonna Judd on Thursday tweeted a thank you to Leach "for being accountable & apologizing to Mom." The scene and heard
Justin Bieber better not climb into a ring, or octagon, with Ronda Rousey . She's not impressed. The UFC bantamweight champ told Cosmopolitan.com that Bieber snubbed her 17-year-old sister in 2014 at the Cannes Film Festival. Bieber was "really rude" when her sister asked for an autograph, Rousey said. "Yeah, I don't think I'd want to hang out with him. I'm not a Belieber. I was, but I'm not anymore." On this day
Oct. 9, 1957: Singer Bobby Darin , at 22, becomes the youngest performer to headline at the Sands' Copa Room, the premier Las Vegas showroom of its time and the favorite hangout of the Rat Pack . The previous youngest headliner was Johnny Mathis , at 23.
Oct. 10, 1987: Olympics champions Florence Griffith and Al Joyner drive from Los Angeles to Las Vegas for an impromptu wedding, nine days after an earthquake scares her into thinking she might die before she gets married. She dies tragically in her sleep 11 years later. Sightings
Chaz Dean of Bravo's "Flipping Out," with staffers from his salon, meeting with Celine Dion before her show Wednesday. The punch line
" Vladimir Putin celebrated his 63rd birthday today. He had a nice party, but it got awkward when two of his friends got him the same country." — Jimmy Fallon 
— Norm Clarke's column appears Sunday, Monday, Wednesday and Friday. He can be reached at 702-383-0244 or norm@reviewjournal.com . Find more online at www.normclarke.com . On Twitter: @Norm_Clarke .
